message_1: Find the fundamental group of the space obtained by removing the origin from the plane, i.e. $\mathbb{R}^2$ without the point $(0,0)$.
message_2:
To find the fundamental group of the punctured plane, we will use the fact that the fundamental group of a space is invariant under deformation retraction. 

Consider the punctured plane $\mathbb{R}^2 \setminus \{(0,0)\}$. We can deformation retract this space onto the unit circle $S^1$. To see this, define a homotopy $H: \mathbb{R}^2 \setminus \{(0,0)\} \times [0,1] \to \mathbb{R}^2 \setminus \{(0,0)\}$ by

$$H(x,t) = (1-t)x + t\frac{x}{\|x\|}$$

for $x \in \mathbb{R}^2 \setminus \{(0,0)\}$ and $t \in [0,1]$. This homotopy starts at the identity map when $t=0$ and ends at the deformation retraction onto the unit circle when $t=1$. 

Since the fundamental group is invariant under deformation retraction, we have that the fundamental group of the punctured plane is the same as the fundamental group of the unit circle:

$$\pi_1(\mathbb{R}^2 \setminus \{(0,0)\}) \cong \pi_1(S^1)$$

The fundamental group of the unit circle $S^1$ is well-known to be isomorphic to the integers:

$$\pi_1(S^1) \cong \mathbb{Z}$$

Therefore, the fundamental group of the punctured plane is isomorphic to the integers:

$$\pi_1(\mathbb{R}^2 \setminus \{(0,0)\}) \cong \mathbb{Z}$$
